### addEdgeBypassingCostAllocator() {#afcecda660b0c5e6a15096abc9e1dffb9}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;typename OtherMatrixPtrT&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>NodeId llvm::PBQP::Graph&lt; SolverT &gt;::addEdgeBypassingCostAllocator (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/pbqp/graphbase/#a7187d2e408994bd7307a4c8f32f745a8">NodeId</a> N1Id, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/pbqp/graphbase/#a7187d2e408994bd7307a4c8f32f745a8">NodeId</a> N2Id, OtherMatrixPtrT Costs)</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Add an edge bypassing the cost allocator.

<ParametersList title="Parameters">
<ParametersListItem name="N1Id">First node.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="N2Id">Second node.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="Costs"><a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#a19921a3ceb99548f498d3df118eda9ed">Cost</a> matrix for new edge.</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
Edge iterator for the added edge.
</SectionUser>

This method allows for fast addition of an edge whose costs don&#39;t need to be passed through the cost allocator. The most common use case for this is when duplicating costs from an existing edge (when using a pooling allocator). These have already been uniqued, so we can avoid re-constructing and re-uniquing them by attaching them directly to the new edge.

### disconnectEdge() {#a0fc861a44ceb8e7b9ad83ff1376990b8}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;typename SolverT&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>void llvm::PBQP::Graph&lt; SolverT &gt;::disconnectEdge (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/pbqp/graphbase/#a679643c1e5202061ef3e9b121a2a7dce">EdgeId</a> EId, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/pbqp/graphbase/#a7187d2e408994bd7307a4c8f32f745a8">NodeId</a> NId)</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Disconnect an edge from the given node.

Removes the given edge from the adjacency list of the given node. This operation leaves the edge in an &#39;asymmetric&#39; state: It will no longer appear in an iteration over the given node&#39;s (NId&#39;s) edges, but will appear in an iteration over the &#39;other&#39;, unnamed node&#39;s edges.

This does not correspond to any normal graph operation, but exists to support efficient <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/pbqp">PBQP</a> graph-reduction based solvers. It is used to &#39;effectively&#39; remove the unnamed node from the graph while the solver is performing the reduction. The solver will later call reconnectNode to restore the edge in the named node&#39;s adjacency list.

Since the degree of a node is the number of connected edges, disconnecting an edge from a node &#39;u&#39; will cause the degree of &#39;u&#39; to drop by 1.

A disconnected edge WILL still appear in an iteration over the graph edges.

A disconnected edge should not be removed from the graph, it should be reconnected first.

A disconnected edge can be reconnected by calling the reconnectEdge method.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/include/llvm/codegen/pbqp/graph-h/#l00625">625</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/include/llvm/codegen/pbqp/graph-h">Graph.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

## Private Member Functions

### addConstructedEdge() {#a58fdcbe2b28c54109c4df739356edbe8}
